questions.text: How many individuals are allocated to one ASHA worker for the population in rural areas?
Which of the following is not considered a pillar of primary health care?
questions.explanation:
Equitable distribution (Option D ruled out):
  • Equitable distribution of health services irrespective of their socio-economic status.

Intersectoral coordination (Option B ruled out):
  • Involves collaboration from other sectors like agriculture, education, etc.
  • Maintains good health.

Appropriate technology (Option c ruled out):
  • Use of technology that is accessible, affordable, and suitable for the community
  • Eg:
    • ORS
    • VVM (Vaccine Vial Monitor): Heat sensitive label
    • Shakir tape: Malnutrition grading
    • Kangaroo mother care: Preterm care

Community participation:
  • Ensure the participation of the community in planning, implementing and maintaining.
  • For the promotion and maintenance of their health.
  • Eg: ASHA workers are residents of the same community.

questions.text: Which entity is responsible for overseeing the school health programs?
questions.explanation:
Level

Name

Function

Population Coverage

Staffing

1

Sub-Centers (SCs) (Option C ruled out)

First point of contact for the community, providing basic healthcare services like immunization, maternal and child health, and health education.

5,000 people in plain areas, 3,000 in hilly/tribal areas

1 Female Health Worker (ANM) and 1 Male Health Worker

2

Primary Health Centers (PHCs)

Provides integrated curative and preventive healthcare services for rural populations. Focuses on maternal and child health, immunization, and family planning.

Serves 30,000 people

Managed by a Medical Officer with supporting healthcare staff

3

Block Primary Health Center (Block PHC)

Referral point for PHCs within the block, providing maternal and child health services, basic surgeries, and diagnostics.

Serves a block population (typically 30,000–50,000 people)

Medical Officer, Nurses, Lab Technicians

4

Community Health Centers (CHCs)

Serves as a referral point for PHCs and provides specialized care.

Serves 80,000 to 1,20,000 people

Staffed with specialists (e.g., surgeons, obstetricians, pediatricians)

5

Sub-Divisional Hospitals (SDHs) (Option D ruled out)

Provides more advanced care than PHCs or CHCs at the sub-divisional level, offering a broader range of medical services and treatments.

Sub-divisional coverage

Specialists, General Medical Practitioners

6

District Hospitals (Option B ruled out)

Provide secondary care services and act as referral points for CHCs. Services include emergency care, surgeries, and specialized treatments.

District-level coverage

Specialists, General Medical Practitioners

7

Tertiary Care Hospitals

Provide advanced medical care and specialized services, such as complex surgeries and treatment for rare conditions.

Multi-district coverage

Highly trained specialists in various medical fields

questions.text: The minimum requirements of a health worker job are given: should be a woman, a resident of the village, 25 to 45 years old, and have a formal education till 8th standard. What is the health worker called?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - ASHA worker

ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist)

ASHA is a woman (married, divorced, or widowed) resident of the village, aged 25-45 years, with education up to 8th grade.

Population Norm for ASHA

The general norm is 1 ASHA per 1000 population. In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, this may be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation.

Role and Responsibilities of ASHA
  • Health Activist: Create awareness and provide information on health determinants, existing services, and the importance of health and family welfare.
  • Counselor: Provide counseling on birth preparedness, safe delivery, and family planning.
  • Mobilizer: Help the community access health services, such as immunizations, sanitation, and nutrition.
  • Provider: Offer basic care for common illnesses and first-aid, and act as a depot for essential medications.
  • Community Engagement: Work with village health committees and panchayats for planning and awareness.

Specific Responsibilities of ASHA
  1. Promote health and sanitation practices.
  2. Advise on child care, immunization, and reproductive health.
  3. Assist with family planning and treatment of minor ailments.
  4. Mobilize pregnant women and children to health services
  5. Provide basic medical care and support for diarrhea, fever, and tuberculosis (under DOTS).
  6. Serve as a depot holder for essential drugs and medical supplies.

Role and Integration with Anganwadi

The Anganwadi worker helps guide ASHA, particularly in organizing Health Day activities, mobilizing village women and children, and promoting nutrition and health education.

Role and Integration with ANMs (Auxiliary Nurse Midwives)

ANMs guide ASHA in areas like immunization, safe pregnancy, and health education, and assist in organizing Health Days. ANMs also help with training and monitor ASHA's performance.

Intersectoral coordination (Option B)

Appropriate technology (Option C)

  • Eg:
    • ORS

    • Shakir tape: Malnutrition grading
    • Kangaroo mother care: Preterm care

Community participation

  • Ensure the participation of the community in planning, implementing and maintaining.
  • For the promotion and maintenance of their health.

questions.text: Universal health coverage (UHC) means that all people and communities receive the quality health services they need, without financial hardship. Which of the following are the challenges to implementing UHC?

options.label: A
options.text: Inequalities in the distribution, adequate support and access to quality assured products only in low income setting

options.label: B
options.text: The purpose of UHC is to find a balance between countries' income, health provision and financial burden

options.label: C
options.text: To provide healthcare to everyone regardless of the countries' income

options.label: D
options.text: UHC only deals with financial aspect of health and cannot cover health provision to all

questions.correct_answer: C. To provide healthcare to everyone regardless of the countries' income
questions.explanation:
Principle

Explanation

Equitable Access

Everyone should receive healthcare regardless of socioeconomic status.

Financial Protection

Out-of-pocket expenses should not cause financial hardship.

Quality Care

Services should be effective, safe, and patient-centered.

Sustainability

Health systems should be designed for long-term viability.

Challenge

Reason

Limited Financial Resources

Low-income countries struggle to fund universal healthcare.

Healthcare Workforce Shortage

Lack of trained professionals, especially in rural areas.

Infrastructure Gaps

Inadequate hospitals, equipment, and medical supply chains.

Political and Policy Barriers

Differences in government commitment to UHC implementation.

Strategy

Description

Innovative Financing

Public-private partnerships, health insurance schemes, and global funding.

Technology Integration

Telemedicine and digital health solutions to expand access.

International Support

WHO and global organizations aiding low-income countries.
